title: Documentation: clarify implicit vs. explicit chaining
body:
I have read attentively the **“Chain” Methods** section of the great Lodash documentation (BTW, it would be nice to have anchors on sections too), but a nuance was still escaping me.

I was wondering what was the difference between `_(something)` and `_.chain(something)`. I saw that one does implicit chaining while the other was doing explicit chaining, but I didn't understand the difference between the two... Code didn't help, I only saw that the latter did the former and added a `__chain__` boolean (used in lot of places, hard to track).

Then I finally found the fine (short and clear) article https://blog.mariusschulz.com/2015/05/14/implicit-function-chains-in-lodash clarifying the issue.

So I came here, to suggest some additional information in the documentation.

Perhaps replacing "Methods that retrieve a single value or may return a primitive value will automatically end the chain returning the unwrapped value. Explicit chaining may be enabled using _.chain." with:
"Methods that retrieve a single (non-collection) value or may return a primitive value will automatically end the chain returning the unwrapped value. Otherwise, the value at the end of the chain must be unwrapped with _#value(). Explicit chaining may be enabled using _.chain and must be finalized with ._#value()."

and in _.chain, replace "Creates a lodash object that wraps value with explicit method chaining enabled." with:
"Creates a lodash object that wraps value with explicit method chaining enabled. The result of such method chaining must be unwrapped with _#value()."

Obviously, feel free to fix my broken English, to modify the sentences any way you want, etc.

title: Add ES2015 compliant lodash(..).next() iterator
body:
As previously discussed this adds the opportunity for users to use a lodash instance in a `for...of` loop or in any native/non-native JS interface which accepts an iterator.

Further, as we've discussed, I'd like to see this as a stepping stone to implementing lodash chains through iterators (https://github.com/megawac/lodash/commit/22e7beb36382dab224ea091cdcd0f9218039d1bc#commitcomment-12960941)

title: Feature request: Deep unset()
body:
I'm not sure if this the correct place to make a feature request...

I'm looking for a way to delete an attribute from an object using a deep path similar to _.set(). It doesn't look like lodash currently supports this.

I thought a reasonable name for this function would be _.unset(). Also it would be nice if it returned the value of the attribute before it was deleted from the object, or undefined if the path does not exist.

Assuming there's not a reason against adding this functionality, I would be interested in contributing this enhancement if it's not a super quick change for someone that's experienced with the lodash source. I'm just starting to read through the contributing doc.

Thanks.

Omit nested properties
body:
Sorry if am posting in the wrong place.

I am looking for a variant of omit function that support nested properties. Example: 

``` js
var obj = {a:{b:{c:1,d:2}};
var res = _.omit(obj, 'a.b.d'); // res = {a:{b:{c:1}}
```

Does it already exist? If not, how complicated is it to implement?

Thanks.

title: Consider removing exit iteration by explicitly returning false, due to es6 arrow function implicitly returning values
body:
Consider the line:

`_.forEach([{a:true}, {a: true}], (x) => x.a = false)`

which implicitly returns false, mutating the array to be `[{a:false}, {a:true}]` - probably not what the programmer intended to do here.

(I understand underscore and the underscore build don't exit iteration on false returns)

Or everybody will need to trip up to see that they should be doing this for those special occasions:

`_.forEach([{a:true}, {a: true}], (x) => {x.a = false})`

A suggestion: introduce a `_.break()` method which exits iterations?

title: Standard utils lib
body:
I know, its a kinda bold move but, what if:
1. We create an organization called "standard-utils" or similar
2. Create a repository for every lodash function
3. Allow contributions for every possible utility function, without to fear a big total build size, because there will be no single final build at all.
4. Build every function as small and independent as possible, take the trade off of having bigger total size. Most projects need just a bunch of functions anyways.
5. Just one way to include functions, there should be no different build types to avoid duplication.

**Just one goal in mind:** a standard set of utilities every other lib can use and though achieve an overall smaller size of applications and finally STOP the madness of utility functions being created in every lib over and over.

title: _.property: add an optional parameter defaultObject

``` js
var getter = _.property('foo.bar', obj);
getter(); // returns obj.foo.bar
```

title: new function isNil ?
Support spread (*.) in _.get
WIP - #1370 Add support for negative indices
body:
This is a POC implementation for supporting negative indices. There are several performance regressions and shortcuts.

Negative indices are a common pattern that make it easy for developers to get the last, 2nd-last, value in an array.

The way the implementation was added, it'd have far reaching implications.

``` js
_.result(['a','b','c'], -3) //=> 'a'
_.get(['a','b','c'], -2) //=> 'b'
_.at(['a','b','c'], -1) //=> ['c']
```

It's also possible to support a path push notation where `a[-0]` could indicate the array location after the last location. This was brought up by #1315.

``` js
_.set({ a: [1] }, 'a[-0]', 2) //=> { a: [1, 2] }
```

@jridgewell and I paired on this.

title: add `reductions` fn from Clojure world
why isNumber is not isNumeric ?
body:
I've read closed issues (not refering and no reopening to reduce mess), but not found strict answer. Looks like to use `isNumber()` is expected by LODASH to have pre-casted value from string (if such). So is it correct and designed logic?

`_.isNumber(2.3)` => true
and 
`_.isNumber("2.3")` => false.
For sure we can use casting:
`_.isNumber(+"2.3")` => true, but IMHO, it's not OK from LODASH side.

My team balance now between usage either JQUERY isNumeric

```
$.isNumeric -> function ( obj ) {
    return !isNaN( parseFloat(obj) ) && isFinite( obj );
}
```

or our own isNumeric:

```
function isNumeric(data) {
    return !isNaN(parseFloat(data)) && isFinite(data) && data.constructor !== Array;
}
```

or, which we thought is the best choice to RELY) LODASH.isNumber()
No we doubt ...

It looks like we have powerful lodash, but for simple isNumber check we have to have other way (simple casting by + or dedicated function). I think it's not ok.

title: isUndefined violates guidance from eslint
body:
eslint explains why it's a bad practice to check for a value to `=== undefined`.  When addressing eslint issues in our codebase, we started converting those checks over to `_.isUndefined` but then realized that `isUndefined` itself is checking `=== undefined`.

Should `isUndefined` follow the guidance eslint gives and use `typeof foo === 'undefined'`?

http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-undefined

title: Chunk by predicate function
find() using array with null values causes TypeError
body:
Using _.find() with null values in an array causes a TypeError to be thrown if the predicate looks for property values. For example:

```
var array = new Array(5);
_.find(array, {id: 1});
```

... throws:

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'id' of null
```

title: Non-integer n values break takeRight, drop, dropRight, others?
body:
I wished to split a list of items into two lists, with roughly even numbers of items in both, making the first list contain one more than the second list if the count was non-even. When exploring how to accomplish this, I ran into an issue due to my dividing the list count by 2 and using that value as the n value in the `take` and `takeRight` functions. Obviously, an odd number divided by 2 will result in a non-integer value. This led me to discover that certain functions, including `takeRight`, `drop`, and `dropRight` will return incorrect or unexpected results when given an n value that is a non-integer. There may be other functions similarly effected, but I have not tested for them. Looking briefly at the tests, it looks like non-integer n values are ignored as a possibility.

Examples and failures:

``` js
> _.VERSION
"3.10.1"

> _.take([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2)
[1, 2]

> _.take([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 3)
[1, 2, 3]

> _.take([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2.5)
[1, 2]
// ^ Seems correct, equivalent of using n = 2

> _.takeRight([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2)
[4, 5]

> _.takeRight([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 3)
[3, 4, 5]

> _.takeRight([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2.5)
[3, 4]
// ^ Failure case, missing the last array value

> _.drop([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2)
[3, 4, 5]

> _.drop([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 3)
[4, 5]

> _.drop([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2.5)
[3, 4]
// ^ Failure case, missing the last array value

> _.dropRight([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2)
[1, 2, 3]

> _.dropRight([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 3)
[1, 2]

> _.dropRight([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2.5)
[1, 2]
// ^ Probably failure case, expected same output as using n = 2

This applies to any non-integer that doesn't implicitly convert to an integer due to precision:

> _.takeRight(list, 2.999999999999999)
[3, 4]

> 2.999999999999999
2.999999999999999

> _.takeRight(list, 2.9999999999999999)
[3, 4, 5]

// Because this number is 3 as far as JS is concerned
> 2.9999999999999999
3
```

title: Allow _.matches or _.matchesProperty to invoke property that is a function

Hi Lodash community!!

I've had an idea to improve `zipObject` function. My English level is very low, sorry, but I can show and example of my idea.

``` js
[ ['test', 1], ['test', 2], ['test4': 3] ] => // before returns {test: 2, test4: 3}
```

I think would be useful that when a prop array is repeated, the result return a property with an array values.

``` js
[ ['test', 1], ['test', 2], ['test4': 3] ] => // now returns {test: [1,2], test4: 3}
```

With this commit, I've modified code to work this.

I hope that my contribution will be useful.

title: _.sum bug in 3.10.1
_.pluck() bug with 'aaa.bbb' dotted-string field selector
body:
`_.pluck([{aaa: null}, {aaa: null}], 'aaa')` returns `[null, null]` - and that's expected

But `_.pluck([{aaa: {bbb: null}}, {aaa: {bbb: null}}], 'aaa.bbb')` returns `[undefined, undefined]` - and that is wrong... should be `[null, null]`.

Doing it one layer at a time - first plucking `aaa` and then plucking `bbb` in a second call returns the expected `[null, null]`.

Tested using versions 3.8.0 & 3.10.0.

Maybe this is the rubyist in me showing through, but I'd love to be able to use negative indices get elements from right to left.


title: bower update lodash gets *-npm-packages for patch version != 0
body:
Hello.

Here's an extrac of the ouptut of `bower info lodash`

```
...
  - 3.2.3-npm-packages
  - 3.2.2-npm-packages
  - 3.2.1-npm-packages
  - 3.2.0
  - 3.2.0-npm-packages
  - 3.2.0-npm
  - 3.2.0-es
  - 3.2.0-amd
...
```

if this line is specified in a bower.json : 

```
"lodash": "~3.2.0"
```

The command `bower update lodash` will retrieve 3.2.3-npm-packages which does not work client side, because there's no 3.2.3

title: Expose the internal toPath method
body:
I'm building a module that makes a lot of use of `_.get` and `_.set` internally, and I keep finding myself wishing I had access to `toPath`, the method that turns a string path into an array. I don't even need new functionality, I'd just like it to be exposed externally, via `_.toPath` or something.

I'm happy to make a PR for it but wanted to open an issue in case there's some opposition to exposing it.

title: Does lodash have an equivalent for null || undefined?
body:
I tried using underscore's !_.has(object, 'property') but that returns true if the value is set to null or undefined. I don't really see anything in underscore or lodash documentation that simplifies something like:

```
if (this._uuid === undefined || this._uuid === null || this._account_type === undefined || this._account_type === null || this.site_id === undefined || this.site_id === null)
```

short of maybe doing

```
_.chain(this).pick(['_uuid', '_account_type', 'site_id']).values().without(undefined).without(null).isEmpty().value();
```

(Another use case not exactly the same is when I have to chain .without(null).without(undefined) which is annoying)

Thanks. :)

title: Support for npm test in package.json
body:
I'm currently working on an automated test system (https://github.com/jasnell/citgm) that will eventually be integrated with the Node.js CI to perform a kind of smoke-test on Node builds. The test system will check a selection of the most popular modules on npm. The current design automates the steps of performing an `npm install` followed by an `npm test`. Unfortunately, lodash doesn't currently support `npm test`, which forces us to include lodash in our group of "special cases".

It would be great if you could add the following line into your lodash's package.json:

```
  "scripts": {
    "test": "node test/test.js"
  }
```

title: Terminating chains with size()
body:
I often need to filter collections, only to get the size. In other words, I have no use for the filtered collection itself. For example:

``` javascript
_(monsterCollection)
    .filter({ enabled: true })
    .size();
```

It'd be cool if this chain recognized "hey, this is terminated with `size()`, so instead of building up a new collection, I just need to increment a counter!".

Maybe there's already something like this in place? Or maybe this isn't a cost-effective optimization? Any thoughts appreciated!

title: License information in bower.json
body:
Hi,

we are using lodash via bower inside of a project. We need to publish all the license/version informations of libraries we use to our customer. We generate this data automatically by parsing bower,json, package.json and component.json files.

In lodash we have the problem, that when installing via bower:
- the component.json, which has the needed informations is being ignored and not available
- bower.json has no information about license and version

So i would love to get this information into the lodash bower package and i'm willing to do the "hard" work =)

What would be the preferred way?
- Remove component.json from being ignored
- Add the informations to bower.json

I'd prefer the first solution.

Looking forward hearing from you.

title: _.sortBy ignores sort key subproperties
body:
Hello,

Maybe this is the intended behaviour, but the documentation made me think it should work:
[`_.sortBy`](https://lodash.com/docs#sortBy) generates a "_.property style callback" when `iteratee` is a property name. And [`_.property`](https://lodash.com/docs#property) allows for subpath definition per the doc.
Hence I expected `_.sortBy` to "sub-sort" elements when a secondary "key" is provided.

Here is a minimal test case:

``` js
_.pluck(_.sortBy([{a: 'X', b: 1}, {a: 'X', b:0}], 'a.b'), 'b')
// Expected: [0, 1]
// Output: [1, 0]
```

title: Shouldn't _.at be 'length proof'?
body: Its my understanding that lodash "Array" functions require arrays, and "Collection" functions prioritize using the length property but don't need it, and "Object" functions ignore it.   Given these three choices I see how _.at fits in, its an Collection function because, in my definition, adding a length property makes it go ape.  But shouldn't it be smarter?  Honestly I'd be worried to use this function for anything but an array.  In other words, the behavior of this function of objects with a 'length' property violates principles of least surprise.

title: Re-word _.merge docs for clarity
body:
Previously, when scanning the docs, it could easily be accidentally read as:

'...that don't resolve to 'undefined' **in** the destination object.'

(i.e. "in" instead of "into")

Both myself and a collegue read it this way, until we looked at it more closely.

I've attempted re-pharsing it here to remove any ambiguity, although it's a bit more verbose.

Alternatively, we could just put a comma after 'undefined', which would help to separate it from "into the destination object".

title: clone and cloneDeep only call customizer with one argument when a thisArg is specified, as opposed to the intended arguments of value, index/key, and object.
body:
This is due to the customizer, an optional function passed to clone and deepClone, being specified as only taking one argument when it is passed into bindCallback.

```
  return typeof customizer == 'function'
    ? baseClone(value, isDeep, bindCallback(customizer, thisArg, 1))
    : baseClone(value, isDeep);
```

bindCallback will then wrap the customizer in a function that only passes along one argument, so that even though baseClone does try to invoke the function with three arguments, they aren't passed through.

It should be noted that this only happens when a thisArg is passed into clone, without it bindCallback simply passes back the original customizer function, causing no problems.

title: Added example of_.isString()
body:
I thought it would be appropriate to add another example of the _.isString() function. An empty string is usually considered a falsy value but, of course, not when it comes to _.isString().

Just stumbled upon this in the codebase I was working on as it caused a bug.

doc: _.matches(source)
body:
the doc of `_.matches(source)` says:

> For comparing a single own or inherited property value see _.matchesProperty.

However the doc of `_.matchesProperty(path, srcValue)` says:

> Objects are compared by their own, not inherited, enumerable properties.

`_.matchesProperty` does not compare the inherited properties.

Another trivial problem:

the doc of `_.matchesProperty(path, srcValue)` says:

> Creates a function that compares the property value of path on a given object to value. 

the word value at the end should be srcValue.

title: lodash-fp: issues with assign, result, zipObject
body:
Hello, first of all let me thank you for lodash, it is a great library and I cannot imaging programming without it. 

I have started experimenting with lodash-fp and it looks pretty good but I run into some issues. I don't know how much it is due to my lack of knowledge (and sadly documentation) and how much these actually are limitations / defects in lodash-fp. 

The problems I've discovered so far:
1. `_.assign({}, {a:1}, {b:2});` returns `{a:1}` instead if `{a:1,b:2}` (the wrongly placed {} should have no effect)
2. No way to provide a default value to `result`?
3. zipObject(["key1", "value1", ...]) does not work
4. Functions on objects don't get the key parameter - find, map, mapValues, ...

Please see the [demonstration of the problems and more context here](https://github.com/jakubholynet/lodash-fp_issues/blob/master/lodash-fp_issues.ipynb).

Thank you!
